Award.AwardTitle: ASME 2016 Nanoengineering for Medicine and Biology Conference Houston, TX, Feb 21-24, 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1606794-Bao

NSF has made an award in support of student, junior faculty and speaker travel to the ASME 2016 NanoEngineering for Medicine and Biology Conference (NENB) being held in Houston, TX, Feb. 21-24, 2016. The goal of the conference is to bring together leading experts in bioengineering, nanomaterials, biology and medicine to review recent advances in nanoengineering and nanomedicine, including new experimental methods, synthetic approaches, modeling and computational efforts, analyses and innovative methodologies for sensing, quantifying, diagnosing and treating medical disorders using nanoengineering approaches. The program is organized under 5 tracks: Nano-imaging, Nanoparticle-based delivery, Nano and Microfluidics, Modeling of nano-phenomenon, and Nano-materials design. The goal of the conference is well matched to programs supported by Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems (CBET) and Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation (EFRI), which is particularly focused on the development of new technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Supported by the NSF Conference Award (Award Number: 1606794), the ASME 2016 NanoEngineering for Medicine and Biology Conference (NEMB 2016) was held in Houston, TX during Feb. 21-24, 2016. The goal for NEMB 2016 was to bring together leading experts in bioengineering, nanomaterials, biology and medicine to review recent advances in nanoengineering and nanomedicine, including new experimental methods, synthetic approaches, modeling and computational efforts, analyses and innovative methodologies for sensing, quantifying, diagnosing and treating medical disorders using nanoengineering approaches. The NEMB 2016 consisted of 5 tracks, including Nano-imaging, Nanoparticle-based delivery, Nano and Microfluidics, Modeling of nano-phenomenon, and Nano-materials design. These emerging areas have great importance not only for Nano Biosensing and Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems (CBET) but also for Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation (EFIR), especially for the development of new technologies. The NEMB 2016 had a very impressive list of plenary lecturers, including 5 NAE members, 3 of them are also NAS or NAM members.

The intellectual merit of the NEMB 2016 is the combination of engineering and biology with a strong focus in medicine. The conference actively involved a large community of participants, and provided an exciting forum to exemplify the intellectual merit of nano- and micro-technology based biosensing, biotransport, biomechanics and other bioengineering areas in the solution of pressing problems in biology and medicine. Specific research areas covered include imaging enabled diagnostics, nanoparticle-enabled therapeutics and drug delivery, microfluidic devices, materials and manufacturing for nanomedicine, modeling and computation of nano- phenomenon, and innovative nanomaterials design. Key intellectual questions addressed by NEMB 2016 included the sensitivity and specificity in disease detection using nanoparticle imaging probes, efficacy of targeted drug/gene delivery using nanocarriers, multiscale measurement and modeling of nanoparticle transport in vitro and in vivo, and the potential toxicity of nanomaterials for medical applications. These are emerging areas of bionanoengineering, biotransport and biomechanics that have received considerable attention throughout this event. The NEMB 2016 also showcased translational and commercialization efforts, and discussed policy and ethical issues related to nanoengineering applications in medicine.  This NSF conference award enabled us to support travel for the best student participants, provided funding for student poster awards, keynote and tutorial lecturers, and junior faculty track chairs. These activities provided integral opportunities for young researchers to broaden the impact of NEMB 2016. The broader impacts of this NSF conference award include the dissemination of the results of NEMB 2016 to the general public far beyond the ~250 attendees at the conference, with online engagement of 200,000 people through updates via ASME social media (LinkedIn, Facebook, and Twitter); the promotional Email blasts to ~40,000 in the ASME Database; and having NEMB 2016 articles and announcements in ASMENews (to 90,000 mechanical engineers) and ASME SmartBrief (to 35,000 engineers). The conference also attracted new participation beyond the existing community of ASME, especially biologists, physician-scientists and clinicians, and provided numerous networking opportunities to stimulate scientific and technical discussion with and amongst young researchers in bioengineering and nanoengineering, and opportunities for them to mingle with senior investigators.
